Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Understanding the High-to-Mid Latitude Ionospheric Response to Stratospheric Warmings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This effort seeks to develop a better understanding of how the high-to-mid latitude ionosphere is coupled to both the underlying middle atmosphere and to solar and geomagnetic drivers. Goals of the project are: (1) To specify solar, magnetospheric, and geomagnetic drivers during a recent period of low to moderate solar activity and to investigate how the wintertime high and mid-latitude ionosphere responds to these drivers; (2) To specify spatio-temporal variations in middle atmospheric drivers, including polar vortex disturbances and planetary waves throughout the stratosphere, mesosphere, and lower thermosphere over the life cycle of sudden stratospheric warmings; (3) To investigate how the combination of forcing from above (goal 1) and forcing from below (goal 2) controls the high to mid-latitude ionosphere during the periods of sudden stratospheric warmings.

A main objective of the project is to understand the impact of lower atmospheric forcing on the high and mid-latitude ionosphere under conditions when wave fluxes from the lower atmosphere are at the maximum, and solar and magnetospheric fluxes are at the minimum. High-amplitude stratospheric planetary waves that lead to minor and major stratospheric warmings will be investigated, and their impact on the middle and high-latitude ionosphere examined. The focus on large dynamical events with strong vertical coupling holds a promise of discovering new sources and mechanisms of quiet-time ionospheric variability. These goals will be achieved through collaborative analysis of NASA MERRA reanalysis data, MLS and TIMED SABER satellite data, incoherent scatter radars data, and WACCM-X/TIMEGCM modeling efforts.

The project will foster a partnership between MIT and the University of Colorado, and also between disciplines. Undergraduate students will participate in the research at both institutions. The MIT Haystack Observatory REU program aims to attract minority students through integration with the Puerto Rican university system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A sudden stratospheric warming (SSW) is one of the most radical changes of weather observed on our planet, and produces a number of intriguing atmospheric features. Within several days, North Pole temperatures can increase by more than 50 K (90 degrees in Fahrenheit) in an SSW event. Several years ago, Haystack researchers have discovered that, contrary to previous ideas, the effects of sudden stratospheric warmings do not merely stay in the stratosphere. Instead, large and dramatic disturbances are also observed far above the stratosphere in the charged part of the upper atmosphere, or ionosphere, at altitudes from 200 to 800 km.

In the course of this project, we focused on several aspects:

1)    understanding effects of SSW at middle to high latitudes, and from mesosphere to ionosphere

2)    understanding evolution of mesospheric polar vortex (Harvey et al., 2018, 2019; JGR-Atmosphere editor's highlights.

3)    investigating night-time changes during SSW (Goncharenko et al;., 2018; JGR-Space Physics editor's highlights)

4)    investigating large-scale coupling between Arctic stratosphere and Antarctic ionosphere (Goncharenko et al., 2020, under review)

5)    summarizing the state of the knowledge in a book chapter of AGU centennial book series (Goncharenko et al., 2020, in print)

6)    organizing and engaging national and international research community in research on this topic and broad dissemination of results (Pedatella et al., 2018, feature article in EOS).

The feature article in EOS is written for general audience and describes recent advances in understanding strong connection between sudden stratospheric warmings and extensive changes throughout Earth?s atmosphere. These changes can affect atmospheric chemistry, temperatures, winds, neutral (nonionized particle) and electron densities, and electric fields (Figure 1), and they extend from the surface to the thermosphere and across both hemispheres. These changes span regions that scientists had not previously considered to be connected. Understanding these coupling mechanisms has practical importance: SSWs open the door for improved tropospheric and space weather forecasting capabilities. The implications extend not only to weather forecasting here on the surface but also to greater understanding of chemical processes in the atmosphere, the sources of adverse effects on satellite navigation systems (e.g., GPS) and telecommunications, and possibly even the study of atmospheres on other planets.

The project provided multiple opportunities for the education and training of undergraduate students. As both PI and Co-I are females with strong commitment to mentoring female students and underserved communities, most of the students were females. Every year, a new undergraduate student started contributing to this work during summer internships funded by the NSF REU program. Most of them continued their effort through the fall semester as an independent research project, presented their results at the Fall AGU meetings, and are currently attending graduate schools. In one case, a first-generation student from rural Kentucky, Mary Spraggs (REU 2014), continued her work on this project from summer 2014 until August 2016. In addition to teaching this student valuable work skills and fostering her interest in atmospheric science, the project provided her with financial support until graduate school.  Ms. Spraggs is currently a graduate student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Department of Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences, and a co-author on two publications on this project. Another student, Mr. Andre Hernandez-Espiet, formerly a high school student from Puerto Rico, is currently an undergraduate student majoring in mathematics and computer science at the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, and a coauthor on one publication. Ms. Jolene Fong (REU 2016), a minority female student, is considering attending a graduate school. All of students obtained valuable STEM skills while working on a project and are pursuing STEM-related degrees.
